ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of recorded lectures and live virtual lectures/discussion sections.
Videos prior to section that we had to watch, in addition to a live virtual seminar.

The class sections were small and split up by professor, but we learned most of the content through Canvas videos, textbook readings, and reading quizzes. The professors debriefed the readings with us and assigned us a few Jamboard practice problems to work on in small groups at each class session.
Watch recorded lecture before each class session, and during each class session, the TA or professor will explain the concept.
There were also recorded videos in addition to the live lectures.
Readings from textbook, watching short videos from professor

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Multivariable calculus, double and triple integrals, understanding of various coordinate systems.
I became a better math student by learning multivariable calculus.
I learnt more about multivariable calculus.
I learned the fundamentals of multivariable calculus (vectors & vector fields, partial derivatives & gradients, 3D geometry, etc.) and a few of their applications to other areas.
Time management and how to think and do math in 3-dimension.
Solid overview of calculus up to three variables, as expected. Some proofs included in textbook and explained at discretion of the professor.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The combination of textbook readings, video lectures, and virtual classes was somewhat redundant- we ended up going over the same material a lot when in reality the psets were the most valuable teaching tool. The pacing was reasonable and the exams were fair.

The strengths of the course were the access to resources for help, and clear instructions regarding all homework and assignments.
The primary weakness was the lack of participation during class.

The course was good in that it was a comprehensive and consistent sweep of multivariable calculus. However, the fact that the videos were recorded beforehand was not effective - it basically meant that we had to know what we were supposed to learn already before even coming into class.

Strengths: PROFESSOR HALL & PEER TUTORS. Hall was the head professor for Math 120 in the fall and recorded all of the videos (+ accompanying notes). Super helpful, thorough, and punctual- he answers all your questions and you can go to his office hours even if you're not in his section. USE HIM AS A RESOURCE. Peer tutors are also great, really casual and friendly and can help you through tough problems.
Weaknesses: each professor got to decide how to award participation grades but weren't super clear about their policies, so many of us didn't know how our participation would get graded until closer to the final. (It's only worth 5% of your grade but still annoying). I also didn't get a lot out of the reading quizzes, and I wish we were given more time for some of the longer videos (which often just repeated what was in the textbook).

Strengths: a lot of students are also struggling so I don't feel shy when asking questions; helpful peer tutor
Weakness: The concepts are hard, hence a lot of students struggled.

Strengths: Effectively achieves what it sets out to do (teach the course material, but not much more...
Weaknesses: Effectively, you cover each topic four times in this class (in the textbook, in the video, in class, and in the problem sets). Personally,  this felt quite redundant, but could be helpful for others. It also made the actual class component difficult to be engaged with, especially over Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The video lectures were helpful, but I think attendance to class could be made optional without significant detriment to the learning process. I would have felt comfortable learning the content solely through the textbook and videos and then having class geared toward practice problems and answering questions, without requiring the full hour and fifteen minutes of attendance.

The virtual format was successful in presenting material and learning new topics.
The office hours could have been improved, because it was difficult/unreasonable to sit in a zoom meeting and listen to other students' questions as you might in person.
The project was an interesting and novel way to work virtually.

I liked the asynchronous format of the course content- it helped me to be able to go at my own pace and watch the videos on my own time (and ask questions in the section if needed). 
I don't think it helped a lot of people to have to take a midterm two days before moveout. I was enrolled remotely so it wasn't a problem for me, and hopefully it won't be too much of a problem this semester, but the timing of the third midterm and some of the assignments weren't supportive to students.

Success: recorded lecture from John Hall
Can be improved: better professors/TAs for each individual class session
See above, unnecessary amount of re-reviewing topics

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the material relatively well, but I did not particularly enjoy the class.
Yes, this course met all my expectations and was appropriately challenging. I think that it teaches necessary math concepts as well.
Yes, it is needed for most STEM majors. It is incredibly  difficult, but necessary.

Yes- if you've taken Calc BC in high school or Math 115/118 the previous semester then this is the logical next step. The workload is a lot, but the pacing seemed reasonable and there are lots of resources to use (Hall, peer tutors, Ximera, etc.). Just make sure you ask questions whenever you need to and check your own understanding.
Only take it if you need to

Likely, you're only alternative to this class is 230/231. Frankly, if you have enough time, take the alternative. I had the opportunity to engage/participate in that class concurrently with 120, and I found 230 a much more engaging and enjoyable course. However, as I said, IF you have the TIME  big if. 120 is much more standard, much easier, but much less inspiring.
